<small><em>Original: 1805.04508v1.json</em></small>

## 📊 Benchmark Details

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Name</strong></td><td>
Equity Evaluation Corpus
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Overview</strong></td><td>
The Equity Evaluation Corpus (EEC) consists of 8,640 English sentences specifically designed to examine biases towards certain races and genders across various sentiment analysis systems.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Data Type</strong></td><td>
Text
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Domains</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Natural Language Processing</li>
<li>Sentiment Analysis</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Languages</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>English</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Similar Benchmarks</strong></td><td>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Resources</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://saifmohammad.com/WebPages/Biases-SA.html">Resource</a></li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
</table>

## 🎯 Purpose and Intended Users

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Goal</strong></td><td>
To provide a benchmark dataset to analyze gender and race biases in sentiment analysis systems.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Target Audience</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Researchers</li>
<li>Developers</li>
<li>Data Scientists</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Tasks</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Evaluate sentiment intensity predictions regarding race and gender bias.</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Limitations</strong></td><td>
The EEC is not a catch-all for all biases but rather a means to examine fairness in sentiment analysis systems.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Out of Scope Uses</strong></td><td>
</td></tr>
</table>

## 💾 Data

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Source</strong></td><td>
Equity Evaluation Corpus compiled from various templates.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Size</strong></td><td>
8,640 sentences
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Format</strong></td><td>
Text
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Annotation</strong></td><td>
Sentences chosen to reveal bias towards gender and race.
</td></tr>
</table>

## 🔬 Methodology

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Methods</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Statistical tests to compare predicted scores</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Metrics</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Intensity scores</li>
<li>Statistical significance (t-tests)</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Calculation</strong></td><td>
Mean difference of predicted scores between sentences differing only in gender or race.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Interpretation</strong></td><td>
Assessment of bias based on differences in predicted sentiment intensity scores.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Baseline Results</strong></td><td>
Baseline SVM system showed small biases with 0.03 maximum score difference across gender pairs.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Validation</strong></td><td>
Statistical significance established using paired two-sample t-tests.
</td></tr>
</table>

## ⚠️ Targeted Risks

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Risk Categories</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Bias in Sentiment Analysis</li>
<li>Discrimination in NLP Systems</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Atlas Risks</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li><strong>Fairness:</strong> Data bias</li>
<li><strong>Societal Impact:</strong> Impact on affected communities</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Demographic Analysis</strong></td><td>
Biases were statistically analyzed across gender and race.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Potential Harm</strong></td><td>
Potential perpetuation of human biases in machine learning systems could lead to negative experiences for affected groups.
</td></tr>
</table>
